publicationStmt.publisher: The Characters that shaped the Silk Road - A Database and Digital Paleography of Tarim

history.provenance: found in ŠorčuqStadthöhleduring T III Š 72.07

sourceDesc.p: Transcription and references have been transferred from the "Text and Reference Database of the Tocharian A Language" (Gerd Carling Lund University) (funded by the Bank of Sweden Tercentenary Foundation and SCAS).
Transcription and translation are based on .

seg.seg: (to a beauti)ful woman he who loves his life shall not go. Therefore this one as [she is] affiliated to my relative and mainly in her
being beautiful to look at must not be made aware of the love. Again he thinks: But who would,

Wiederum denkt er: "Wer könnte aber, wenn er ein so schönes Mädchen an solchem Ort und zu solcher Zeit gefunden hat, sich zurückhalten? Warum sollte ich nicht aus Liebe (zu) ihr ein Gespräch führen? Oder ob ich zuvor nach ihrer Hand fasse?"

Again he thinks: "But who could restrain himself, after having found such a beautiful girl in such a place at such a time? Why should I not, out of love for her, hold a conversation? Or should I reach for her hand before?"
having found such a beautiful girl in such a place and at such a time, be able to restrain oneself? Why should I not
have a conversation because of love to her? Or what if I take her by the hand before? When the painter then, full of love,
Or what if I take her by the hand before? (cf 10; 259)

Als dann der Maler voll Liebe nach der Hand des künstlichen Mädchens fasste, zerbrach der Mechanismus sofort, auseinander fielen seine Lappen, Schnüre(?) [und] Holzpflöcke(,), und es war kein (Mädchen).
When the painter then, full of love, reached out for the hand of the artificial girl, the mechanism broke immediately, the rags, strings(?) [and] wooden pegs fell apart, and there was no (girl).
reached for the hand of the artificial girl, this one immediately broke assunder, and her rags, ropes [and] pins fell apart,
and there was no longer (a girl). When the painter saw this, he rose as distraught from his bed and after a regarding it well,
(he says): O dear! I have been terribly deceived/ridiculed by the master mechanic! Oh such [is] the power of passion! Oh what
O dear! I have been terribly deceived by the master mechanic! Oh such [is] the power of passion! Oh such [is] the horror of ignorance! If a being loves mere rags so intensely!
Ach die Kraft der Leidenschaft, ach die Macht der Dummheit, wenn ein Mensch schon zu Lappen so heftig Liebe fasst!
Alas, the power of passion, alas the power of foolishness, if man falls in love [lit. seizes love] so deeply with mere rags!
horror/awesome power of ignorance, when a human being so intensely falls in love with mere rags! But it is a very true statement of the good/wise ones
when they say: there is nothing in the self, by the beings the conception of the self has been made. And in truth
there is no self. || In the Y.-tune: || Just like of the ones composed of rags, pins [and] ropes my imagination was this,
just so of the ones composed of bones, flesh and sinews is the self-imagination of the beings.
If I examine the body parts one by one, there is nothing called “the self”. (cf 11; 260)
If I examine the body parts one by one, there is nothing here called "self". As my love was towards rags, (just so...)

p.note: The translation is largely based on 10-11, and .

div.p: Edition7. Siegling's personal copy of p. 7.

list.item: a1 -tsonāṃ k_uleyacä\ śo_l\ kulypa_m_antā_p\ mā yä_l\ _t_amyo sās ñi ṣñaṣṣeyā_p\ ṣñi lyutār pāk śkaṃ – a2 -tsi k_r_aṃtso nasluneyā mā yātalyi tuṅ= śär_s_assi nuna_k\ _p_a_lt_s_aṅkāṣ kus nu cämpi_ṣ\ taṃne k_r_aṃ – a3 -nāṃ taṃne tkanā taṃne tkanā taṃne praṣtā _k_alpo_r_a_ṣ\ āñcä_m\ sā_k_assi kyal mā _n_aṣ tā – a4 tuṅkyo plāc wāwi_m\ kupre pat nu tsarā ne_ṣ\ eṃtsmā_r-_aṃ _t_m_aṣ pekan_t\ śla tuṅ_k\ yan_t_arṣi – a5 – mine tsarā eṃtsu_r_a_ṣ\ _t_m_a_k _s_am yaṃ_t_a_r\ weka_t\ _p_k_an_t\ _p_k_an_t\ kratswañä\ śorkmi ṣutkmi klā_r-_aṃ – a6 – [m]ā śkaṃ tā_k\ _t_a_m _p_alko_r_a_ṣ\ pekan_t\ wi«yo» =ki lakeyä_ṣ\ kā_k_atku āneñci _p_alko_r_a_ṣ\ – – b1 – · [ai] ṣokyo nu ka_k_atwu tākā yaṃtrācāreṃ _k_aṣṣinā ote _t_apreṃ eṅklis tampewātsune [o] – – b2 – ākntsuneyi_s\ empelune kratswsaṃ kar wraso_m _t_apreṃ prā_k_ar tuṅk yāmt_r_a ṣokyo nu krañcäśśi kārme – b3 -ñlune kuc ne _t_a_m\ t_r_aṅkiñcä\ mā na_ṣ\ āñmaṃ wrasaśśi āñmaṣi īme yāmu wäṣ[p]ā – b4 -nu āñcä_m\ mā na_ṣ\ || ylaṃ || kratswa_s\ ṣu_t_k_m_a_s\ śor_k_m_asyo _m_alkoñcsaṃ ṣya_k\ _m_aṃt ne ñi – b5 ime tā_k\ : _t_amne_k\ āyä\ śwā_l\ puskāsyo _m_alkoñcsaṃ ṣya_k\ wrasaśśi āñmaṣ= ime : ka – b6 -ñāṣās pā_k_antu _p_k_an_t\ _p_k_an_t\ potka mā tṣaṃ na_ṣ\ āñcä_m\ ñomā : _m_aṃt ne kratswsaṃ ñi tuṅ_k\ tā[_k\] –

The translation is largely based on [[Sieg, Übers. I]]:10-11, and [[Carling, DThTA]].

b4. The tune has 4x18 syllables, rhythm 7/7/4.

a1 (to a beauti)ful woman he who loves his life shall not go. Therefore this one as [she is] affiliated to my relative and mainly in her a2 being beautiful to look at must not be made aware of the love. Again he thinks: But who would, a3 having found such a beautiful girl in such a place and at such a time, be able to restrain oneself? Why should I not a4 have a conversation because of love to her? Or what if I take her by the hand before? When the painter then, full of love, a5 reached for the hand of the artificial girl, this one immediately broke assunder, and her rags, ropes [and] pins fell apart, a6 and there was no longer (a girl). When the painter saw this, he rose as distraught from his bed and after a regarding it well, b1 (he says): O dear! I have been terribly deceived/ridiculed by the master mechanic! Oh such [is] the power of passion! Oh what b2 horror/awesome power of ignorance, when a human being so intensely falls in love with mere rags! But it is a very true statement of the good/wise ones b3 when they say: there is nothing in the self, by the beings the conception of the self has been made. And in truth b4 there is no self. || In the Y.-tune: || Just like of the ones composed of rags, pins [and] ropes my imagination was this, b5 just so of the ones composed of bones, flesh and sinews is the self-imagination of the beings. b6 If I examine the body parts one by one, there is nothing here called "self". As my love was towards rags, (just so...)

Translations from [[Peyrot, ToSu]]
Lines Translation Pages
a4 Or what if I take her by the hand before? (cf [[Sieg, Übers. I]]: 10; [[Pinault 2008]]: 259) 631
b1-2 O dear! I have been terribly deceived by the master mechanic! Oh such [is] the power of passion! Oh such [is] the horror of ignorance! If a being loves mere rags so intensely! 283
b5-6 If I examine the body parts one by one, there is nothing called “the self”. (cf [[Sieg, Übers. I]]: 11; [[Pinault 2008]]: 260) 250


Translations from [[Schmidt KT 1974]]
Lines Translation Pages
a2-4 Wiederum denkt er: "Wer könnte aber, wenn er ein so schönes Mädchen an solchem Ort und zu solcher Zeit gefunden hat, sich zurückhalten? Warum sollte ich nicht aus Liebe (zu) ihr ein Gespräch führen? Oder ob ich zuvor nach ihrer Hand fasse?" 84, 180, 310, 395
a4-6 Als dann der Maler voll Liebe nach der Hand des künstlichen Mädchens fasste, zerbrach der Mechanismus sofort, auseinander fielen seine Lappen, Schnüre(?) [und] Holzpflöcke(,), und es war kein (Mädchen). 114
b1-2 Ach die Kraft der Leidenschaft, ach die Macht der Dummheit, wenn ein Mensch schon zu Lappen so heftig Liebe fasst! 340


  • b2, translation: [[Carling, DThTA]]: 155 has “good ones”, on p. 147 “wise ones”
  • b1, translation: [[Carling, DThTA]]: 161 has “ridiculed” (TI)
  • b1: [[Sieg, Übers. I]]: 10 restores (h)ai based on Siegling's identification of the remaining vowel as ai instead of e (contra [[TochSprR(A)]]). Therefore, I changed the transliteration from e to [ai]. (BK)
  • a3: [[Pinault 2008]]: 255 restores tā(mac) but according to the transliteration in [[TochSprR(A)]]: 7 there is only enough room to restore a single akṣara. A potential alternative would be to restore tā(m). A double accusative involving the root weñ- is also attested in YQ II.9 b7 (... [āṣānikāṃ metrakäṃacc] weñār [rakeacc]). (BK)

kräṃtsonāṃ|(kräṃ)|tsonāṃ a1 k_uleyac śol kulypamäntāp mā_(TA)|mā yäl tämyo sās ñi ṣñaṣṣeyāp ṣñi lyutār pāk śkaṃ lkātsi|(lkā)|tsi a2 kräṃtso nasluneyā mā_(TA)|mā yātalyi tuṅk|tuṅ= śärsässi nunak pältsäṅkāṣ kus nu cämpiṣ taṃne kräṃtsonāṃ|kräṃ(tso)|nāṃ a3 taṃne tkanā «†taṃne» «†tkanā» taṃne praṣtā kälporäṣ āñcäm sākässi kuyal|kyal mā_(TA)|mā näṣ tā(maṃ) a4 tuṅkyo plāc wāwim kupre pat nu tsarā neṣ eṃtsmār-äṃ tmäṣ pekant śla tuṅk yantärṣi(nāṃ) a5 (śo)mine tsarā eṃtsuräṣ tmäk säm yantär|yaṃtär wekat pkänt pkänt kratswañ śorkmi ṣutkmi klār-äṃ śomiṃ|(śo)|(miṃ) a6 mā_(TA)|mā śkaṃ tāk täm pälkoräṣ pekant wiyo oki|=ki lakeyäṣ kākätku āneñci pälkoräṣ träṅkäṣ|(träṅkä)|(ṣ) b1 hai_(TA)|(h)ai ṣokyo nu kakätwu tākā yaṃtrācāreṃ käṣṣinā ote täpreṃ eṅklis tampewātsune o(te täpreṃ|tä)|(preṃ) b2 ākntsuneyis empelune kratswsaṃ kar wrasom täpreṃ prākär tuṅk yāmtär_(TA)|yāmträ ṣokyo nu krañcäśśi kārme weñlune|(we)|ñlune b3 kuc ne täm träṅkiñc mā_(TA)|mā naṣ āñmaṃ wrasaśśi āñmaṣi ime|īme yāmu wäṣpā penu|(pe)|nu b4 āñcäm mā_(TA)|mā naṣ || ylaṃ || # kratswas ṣutkmäs , śorkmäsyo ; mälkoñcsaṃ ṣyak , mänt|mäṃt ne ñi ; (saṃ) b5 ime tāk : #1a tämnek āy śwāl , puskāsyo ; mälkoñcsaṃ ṣyak , wrasaśśi ; āñmaṣi|āñmaṣ= ime : #1b kapśiṃñāṣās|ka(pśiṃ)|ñāṣās b6 , pākäntu ; pkänt pkänt potka«m» , mā_(TA)|mā tṣaṃ naṣ ; āñcäm ñomā : #1c mänt|mäṃt ne kratswsaṃ , ñi tuṅk tāk ; tämne|(tä|mne-k) #1d

div.p: • translation: <citedRange>155</citedRange></bibl> has “good ones”, on p. 147 “wise ones”</li><li><ref type="ms" target="__b1,"/> translation: <bibl><title corresp="ref:carlingetal2009"/><citedRange>161</citedRange></bibl> has “ridiculed” (TI)</li><li><ref type="ms" target="__b1:"/><bibl><title corresp="ref:sieg1944"/><citedRange>10</citedRange></bibl> restores <hi>(h)ai</hi> based on Siegling's identification of the remaining vowel as <hi>ai</hi> instead of <hi>e</hi> (contra <bibl><title corresp="ref:siegandsiegling1921"/></bibl>). Therefore, I changed the transliteration from <hi>e</hi> to <hi>[ai]</hi>. (BK)</li><li><ref type="ms" target="__a3:"/><bibl><title corresp="ref:pinault2008"/><citedRange>255</citedRange></bibl> restores <hi>tā(mac)</hi> but according to the transliteration in <bibl><title corresp="ref:siegandsiegling1921"/><citedRange>7</citedRange></bibl> there is only enough room to restore a single akṣara. A potential alternative would be to restore <hi>tā(m)</hi>. A double accusative involving the root <hi>weñ-</hi> is also attested in YQ II.9 b7 (... [āṣānikāṃ metrakäṃ<hi rend="subscript">acc</hi>] weñār [rake<hi rend="subscript">acc</hi>]). (BK)</li></ul></p></project_comment>
